Principal InvestigatorMary-Claire KingUniversity of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
Funding SourceR01 MH083989National Institute of Mental Health, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA
Configuration.Description: Schizophrenia is a complex neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by marked genetic heterogeneity. Much of the genetic architecture of the disorder has yet to be explained, but de novo mutations appear to play an important role. We used exome sequencing of parent-offspring quads and trios to detect de novo mutations in persons with schizophrenia. Patients were more likely to harbor one or more damaging de novo mutations, as compared to their healthy siblings. The genes disrupted by damaging mutations in patients operated in processes important to early brain development.
Configuration.StudyInEx:
Probands have schizophrenia, diagnosed using DSM-IV criteria.

Parents and siblings were free of major psychiatric illness.

Header.title: Principal Investigator
Header.Institution: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA

Header.title: Funding Source
Header.Institution: National Institute of Mental Health, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA

Configuration.StudyHistory:
DNA samples were provided by the Center for Collaborative Genomic Studies on Mental Disorders at Rutgers University (NIMH Genetics). Participants who provided samples received a comprehensive psychiatric diagnostic evaluation, including the Diagnostic Interview for Genetic Studies (DIGS) (Nurnberger et al., 1994) and the Family Interview for Genetic Studies (FIGS) (Maxwell, 1996).

Exome sequencing to identify de novo mutations was conducted per the NIH grant MH083989.
